#### Solution:
To write a script for blocking specific websites, you would typically use web filtering software like `ufw` (Uncomplicated Firewall) in Linux systems with appropriate firewall rules added. Below is an example of such commands using UFW which will block all incoming HTTP traffic from specified domains while allowing other services unimpeded. This method assumes your server has SSH enabled on port 22 so remote management remains possible even if standard ports become blocked by this rule set.

1. Open Terminal as root user or switch contexts (`sudo -i`) into superuser mode. If not already installed, install ufw via package manager e.g., `apt-get install ufw`.
    ```sh
    sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install ufw
    ```
    
2. Enable logging within UFW configuration file `/etc/default/ufw`:
   Change 'LOGGING=0' to 'LOGGING=1'. Restarting UFW ensures these changes take effect immediately without restarting systemd processes related to networking.
   ```sh
   echo "LOGGING=1" | sudo tee -a /etc/default
